newsitem.title: HONG KONG: PRESS DIGEST-Hong Kong newspaper headlines-June 10.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST-Hong Kong newspaper headlines-June 10.

text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Hong Kong press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

-- MING PAO -- Beijing sources said President Jiang Zemin would come to Hong Kong to host the handover ceremony. A 600-strong "central journalist group" has been set up to control the wording of reports on major handover events.

-- WEN WEI PO -- The film "The Opium War" saw its opening in Beijing at the Great Hall of the People attended by Chinese leaders including Vice-Premier Qian Qichen. The Chinese national anthem was played at the opening.

-- TA KUNG PAO -- To make it easier for Taiwanese to go to the mainland, the mayor of Fuzhou said Beijing had given it the authority to issue visas to Taiwanese visitors after they land in Fuzhou from June 23.

-- SING TAO -- Sources said the Nanjing military zone would carry out a military exercise in the waters near Taiwan in late June, the same time as Taiwan military exercises, in a move aimed at warning Taiwan not to disturb the Hong Kong handover.

-- EXPRESS NEWS -- Cheung Ka-man, a member of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Committee, said he believed there would be another pro-democracy movement in China in 10 years' time, but the outcome will be different from 1989.

-- ECONOMIC JOURNAL -- Only 80 percent of local hotel rooms are booked for the handover period and more than seven thousand rooms are available, but the Hotel Business Association said the occupancy rate could reach 90 percent during the handover.

-- APPLE DAILY --The Hong Kong Government has prepared 150 Mercedec Benz to serve dignataries during the handover, while a Japanese guest has booked seven Rolls Royce cars through a travel agent for the handover period.
-- SOUTH CHINA MORNING POST -- Chief Executive-designate Tung Chee-hwa described himself as a man of principle who would resign if his beliefs were compromised after the handover.

-- HONGKONG STANDARD -- The Chief Executive's Office will not announce how it is going to solve the problem of young illegal immigrants until after the handover, to avoid a clash with the Governor Chris Patten.
